body: We join with a nil interface though.

True, but that works for me... I.e. I get announcements:

```
[P56IO] 2015/04/02 10:38:53.892354 discover.go:319: DEBUG: discover: Received local announcement from [fe80::1610:9fff:fed3:24b7%en0]:21026 for RPAC4LT-B2TTKPP-LVGRIHC-QO2LV3U-XCJ4K5U-F4W4P76-XNJS46X-TRACIQX
[P56IO] 2015/04/02 10:38:53.892475 discover.go:369: DEBUG: discover: Caching RPAC4LT-B2TTKPP-LVGRIHC-QO2LV3U-XCJ4K5U-F4W4P76-XNJS46X-TRACIQX addresses: [{172.21.21.196:22000 2015-04-02 10:38:53.891947947 +0200 CEST} {[fe80::1610:9fff:fed3:24b7%en0]:22000 2015-04-02 10:38:53.892373993 +0200 CEST}]
```

The above error ("discovery unavailable") is printed if we fail to resolve the UDP address or fail to listen. @vhbit If you run with `STTRACE=discover`, what's the actual error quoted by `discover: Start local v6: <some error>`?

Here is the output:

`discover.go:84: DEBUG: discover: Start local v6: listen udp ff32::5222: setsockopt: can't assign requested address`

Moreover, I've patched code from https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/master/internal/beacon/multicast.go#L23 to 

``` go
iface, err := net.InterfaceByName("en0")
if err != nil {
    l.Debugln("failed to find interface by name")
    iface = nil
}

conn, err := net.ListenMulticastUDP("udp", iface, gaddr)
```

and after that local version was able to listen on IPv6, so using correct interface is the case (at least on 10.10).
I can open a PR for that, although a better patch should probably use smarter filter for interface name and OS which requires a little bit more Go knowledge :smile:

I feel we should do it for every v6 interface anyway.
We should also incorporate similar patch for v4 and UPnP in hopes that it makes it more reliable. 

Marking as bug as it seems to fix your situation (even though it's a OS specific issue I guess).

Another fun thing I've also discovered now is that here is output of `lsof -i -n -P | grep syncthing`:

`syncthing 85621 vhbit   20u  IPv6 0x60389c6c5c6673ab      0t0  UDP *:21025`

note that it is somehow bound to IPv6, while 21025 is supposed to be IPv4 only.

> similar patch for v4

It is actually redundant as soon as v4 uses broadcast. I believe that's limitation of multicast sockets only.

one more thought - I've seen mention that v4 uses broadcast because multicast caused problems on Android. I wonder if it was the same issue - requirement to use multicast with an specific interface, it makes a lot more sense for mobile.
I wonder why it works for me on 10.10 then...
I don't seem to have any interfaces that are UP and don't have MULTICAST capability (in ifconfig), only exception is stf0 that is neither. @vhbit what does an ifconfig on your system report?

The same result for `ifconfig` - multicast is enabled on all interfaces but `stf0`.

Patches you've provided make port 21025 IPv4 only, but unfortunately IPv6 is still unbound. I have no ideas why it might happen - if you're using 10.10 the only difference between our setups should be drivers and routers.
OK, so this should probably be refactored for a separate socket (reader+writer) per interface.
JFYI, just reproduced it on old machine with 10.9.

issue.title: Broadcast discovery of servers on a local network
issue.body:
Multicast discovery means that the device enumeration routine can discover devices without an explicit addresses specified.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Service_Discovery_Protocol
